subsection.leadIn: The request must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: include a representation of the trade mark that is proposed to be registered; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify the goods or services (classified in accordance with the International Classification) for which the trade mark is proposed to be registered.

subsection.content: The period prescribed for the purposes of section 72(5)(d) of the Ordinance is the 6-month period beginning on the day after the date on which the Registrar gives a notice of objection under section 72(5)(c) of the Ordinance.
This rule applies where the Registrar is required by section 70 of the Ordinance to give a party to proceedings before him an opportunity to be heard.

The Registrar shall send a notice to the party informing him of the provisions of section 70 of the Ordinance and that if he wishes to have a hearing, he must file a request for a hearing within 1 month after the date of the notice.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar shall, on the filing of a request for a hearing within the period specified in subrule (2) or on the filing of a request for a hearing in accordance with rule 13(5)— (L.N. 97 of 2003)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fix a date, time and place for the hearing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: send a notice of the date, time and place fixed for the hearing to each party to the proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar may in any other case, on his own initiative—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fix a date, time and place for a hearing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: send a notice of the date, time and place fixed for the hearing to each party to the proceedings.

subsection.content: Any party to whom a notice is sent under subrule (3) or (4) and who intends to appear at the hearing shall, within 14 days after the date of the notice, file notice of his intention on the specified form, and any party who fails to do so may be treated as not intending to appear at the hearing, and the Registrar may act accordingly.

A notice sent to any party under rule 21, 39, 45 or 50(10) shall be treated as having been sent to that party in compliance with subrule (4), and subrule (5) shall apply accordingly. (L.N. 97 of 2003)

section.name: s75
section.heading: Registrar not required to hold hearings in certain cases
section.leadIn: The Registrar may decide a matter without a hearing if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Registrar reasonably believes that no party wishes to be heard; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: at least one of the following circumstances applies in relation to each party notified of the hearing in accordance with these Rules—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the party has not indicated to the Registrar that he intends to appear at the hearing;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the party has informed the Registrar that he does not intend to appear at the hearing; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the party does not attend the hearing.

subsection.content: A party, or his representative, as the case may be, may attend a hearing in person or by such means as the Registrar allows.
A party may make representations in writing before or during a hearing.
The Registrar may adjourn a hearing by notifying each party to the hearing accordingly.
Subject to these Rules, the Registrar may give any direction that is reasonably necessary for the conduct of the hearing.

section.name: s77
section.heading: Hearings to be public
section.content: The hearing before the Registrar of any dispute between 2 or more parties relating to any matter in connection with a registered trade mark or an application for registration of a trade mark shall be held in public unless the Registrar, for any of the reasons stated in Article 10 of the Hong Kong Bill of Rights set out in Part II of the Hong Kong Bill of Rights Ordinance (Cap. 383), otherwise directs.

subsection.content: Any party in a hearing before the Registrar, or any witness or expert called to give evidence by such party, may use a language other than the language of the proceedings on condition that, at least 10 days before the date fixed for the hearing, the party gives to the Registrar and to the other parties written notice of his intention to use, or to call a witness or expert who intends to use, a language other than the language of the proceedings.

The Registrar may require a party who gives notice under subrule (1) to make provision for interpretation into the language of the proceedings and may give directions as to who should bear the costs of interpretation.

section.name: s79
section.heading: Evidence in proceedings before the Registrar

subsection.content: Where under the Ordinance or these Rules evidence may be admitted by the Registrar in any proceedings before him, the evidence shall be filed by way of a statutory declaration or affidavit.
The Registrar may in any particular case take oral evidence in addition to any evidence filed by way of a statutory declaration or affidavit.
The Registrar may allow any witness to be cross-examined on his statutory declaration, affidavit or oral evidence.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of any proceedings before the Registrar, a statutory declaration or affidavit may be made and subscribed as follows—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in Hong Kong, before any commissioner, notary or other person authorized by the law of Hong Kong to administer an oath for the purpose of any legal proceeding; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any place outside Hong Kong, before any court, judge, justice of the peace, notary, notary public, consul or other person authorized by law to administer an oath or to exercise notarial functions in that place for the purpose of any legal proceeding.

subsection.content: A person signing a statutory declaration or affidavit shall state on it the capacity in which he makes the declaration or affidavit.

Any document purporting to have affixed, impressed or subscribed to or on it the seal or signature of any person authorized by subrule (1) to take a statutory declaration or affidavit may be admitted by the Registrar without proof of the genuineness of the seal or signature, or of the official character of the person or his authority to take the declaration or affidavit.

A party to any proceedings before the Registrar who files a statutory declaration or affidavit under these Rules may file a photograph or photographs of any exhibit to that statutory declaration or affidavit and may send a copy of the photograph or photographs to any other party to the proceedings to whom a copy of the declaration or affidavit must be sent, in lieu of filing the original of the exhibit or sending a copy of it to that other party.
Photographs filed under subrule (1) must be of sufficient size and clarity to properly depict any details of the exhibit referred to in the statutory declaration or affidavit.

A party who files a photograph under subrule (1) shall at the same time give a written undertaking to the Registrar that he will produce the original of the exhibit whenever required by the Registrar and will make it available for inspection by any other party to the proceedings.
The original of any exhibit for which a photograph is filed under subrule (1) shall be produced at the hearing unless the Registrar otherwise directs.

section.name: s82
section.heading: Leave to file evidence
section.content: Where under any provision of these Rules evidence may be filed in any proceedings before the Registrar only with the leave of the Registrar, the Registrar may refuse such leave or grant leave on such terms as he thinks fit.

section.name: s83
section.heading: Application for leave to be substituted for party

subsection.content: Where a party to any proceedings before the Registrar is a body corporate or other legal entity and the body corporate or legal entity has been wound-up, merged with another body corporate or legal entity or acquired by any person, any person claiming to have an interest in the proceedings may apply to the Registrar in writing for leave to be substituted for that party, stating the nature of his interest, and the Registrar may refuse such leave or grant leave on such terms as he thinks fit.

Where a party to any proceedings before the Registrar assigns or otherwise disposes of any interest in a trade mark, application or other thing that is the subject matter of the proceedings, any person claiming to have an interest in the proceedings may apply to the Registrar in writing for leave to be substituted for that party, stating the nature of his interest, and the Registrar may refuse such leave or grant leave on such terms as he thinks fit.
Any person granted leave under subrule (1) or (2) shall, subject to any terms imposed by the Registrar, be treated as a party to the proceedings before the Registrar.

subsection.leadIn: If any person who neither resides nor carries on business in Hong Kong files—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a notice of opposition to the registration of a trade mark under rule 16;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a counter-statement under rule 17;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a notice of objection to the amendment of an application for registration of a trade mark under rule 26;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: an application for the revocation of the registration of a trade mark under rule 36;

paragraph.name: e
f
g
h
paragraph.content: an application for leave to intervene under rule 51;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: a notice of objection to the alteration of the registration of a trade mark under rule 55;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: an application for leave to be substituted for a party under rule 83; or

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: a notice of opposition or counter-statement under section 15 of the repealed Ordinance in relation to an application for registration of a mark that is advertised under section 14 or 66 of the repealed Ordinance on or after the commencement date,

subsection.continued: the Registrar may require that person to give security for the costs of the proceedings, in such form and in such amount as the Registrar considers appropriate.

subsection.content: If the Registrar requires security to be given by any person and that person fails to give security as required, the Registrar may treat the notice of opposition, notice of objection, counter-statement or application in question as abandoned or withdrawn.
The Registrar may at any stage in the proceedings require further security to be given at any time before giving his decision in the case.
This rule is without prejudice to the Registrar’s power under rule 51(1) to require an undertaking as to costs in relation to an application for leave to intervene.
The Registrar shall have the power to tax any costs awarded by him in any proceedings before him.

In the event of an opposition to the registration of a trade mark being uncontested by the applicant for registration, the Registrar in deciding whether costs should be awarded to the opponent shall consider whether proceedings might have been avoided if reasonable notice had been given by the opponent to the applicant before the notice of opposition was filed.

division.name: D5
division.heading: Case Management Conference and Pre-hearing Review

subsection.content: At any stage of any proceedings before him, the Registrar may direct that the parties to the proceedings attend a case management conference where they shall have an opportunity to be heard with regard to the future conduct of the proceedings, and in particular with regard to the proposed exercise of any of the Registrar’s powers under these Rules.
The Registrar shall give the parties at least 14 days’ notice of the date, time and place of the case management conference.

Before hearing any party that desires to be heard in any proceedings before him, the Registrar may direct that the parties to the proceedings attend a pre-hearing review at which he may give such directions as to the conduct of the hearing as he may think fit.
The Registrar shall give the parties at least 7 days’ notice of the date, time and place of the pre-hearing review.
The Registrar may, at the request of a party to any proceedings before him or on his own initiative, give a direction in relation to the procedure in those proceedings.
A direction given under subrule (1) must not be inconsistent with these Rules.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar shall not give a direction under subrule (1) unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he is reasonably satisfied that the parties to the proceedings have been notified of the proposed direction;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he has given the parties to the proceedings a reasonable opportunity to make representations concerning the proposed direction; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: he is reasonably satisfied that the proposed direction is appropriate.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subrule (3)(b), the representations may be made in writing or at a hearing or by such other means as the Registrar reasonably allows.

section.name: s89
section.heading: Directions to file documents, information or evidence
section.content: At any stage of any proceedings before him, the Registrar may direct that such documents, information or evidence as he may reasonably require shall be filed within such period as he may specify.

section.name: s90
section.heading: Stay of proceedings
section.content: The Registrar may, where he considers it appropriate to do so, stay any proceedings before him involving 2 or more parties on such terms as he thinks fit, and he may do so either on his own initiative or on request of a party to those proceedings.

subsection.content: Where the Registrar has made a decision in any proceedings before him, he shall send a notice to each party to the proceedings informing him of the decision.

Where a statement of the reasons for the decision is not included in the notice, any party may, within 1 month after the date of the notice, file a request on the specified form for a statement of the reasons for the decision, and on receipt of such a request and payment of the applicable fee, the Registrar shall send a statement of the reasons for the decision to each party to the proceedings.
A party who files a request under this rule shall at the same time send a copy of the request to each other party to the proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of any appeal against the Registrar’s decision, the decision shall be deemed to have been made on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date on which the notice of decision is sent under subrule (1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where a statement of reasons is sent under subrule (2), the date on which the statement of reasons is sent.

part.name: P12
part.heading: Amendment of Documents, Rectification of Irregularities and Extension of Time Limits

section.name: s92
section.heading: Amendment of documents
section.content: Subject to any provisions of the Ordinance or these Rules relating to the amendment of applications for registration of trade marks and other documents, any document filed with the Registrar may, if the Registrar thinks fit, be amended on such terms as he may direct.

subsection.content: Subject to subrule (2), any irregularity in procedure in or before the Registry may be rectified on such terms as the Registrar may direct.
No period of time may be extended under this rule.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to rule 95, the Registrar may, on a request being filed on the specified form by the party concerned, extend any period of time—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prescribed by these Rules; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specified by the Registrar for doing any act or taking any proceedings,

subsection.continued: for such period and on such terms, if any, as he may direct.

subsection.content: Where a request for an extension of time is filed under subrule (1) in relation to a period of time prescribed by rule 18, 19, 20, 38, 42, 43, 44, 50(7), 51A(3), 74 (other than rule 74(2)) or 91(2), or in relation to a period of time specified by the Registrar under rule 120(7), the party seeking the extension shall send a copy of the request to every other party to the proceedings. (L.N. 92 of 2025)

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the period within which any party to any proceedings before the Registrar may file evidence under these Rules is to begin on the expiry of any period during which any other party may file evidence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the other party notifies the Registrar that he does not intend to file evidence,

subsection.continued: the Registrar may direct that the period within which the party mentioned in paragraph (a) may file evidence shall begin on such date as may be specified in the direction, and where he issues such a direction he shall notify each party to the proceedings of the relevant date.

subsection.content: Where any person fails to comply with a time limit imposed by the Ordinance or these Rules and the Registrar is satisfied that the failure is attributable in whole or in part to an error or omission of the Registrar or the Registry, he may extend the period of time in question on such terms, if any, as he may direct.

subsection.leadIn: Where it appears to the Registrar that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the absence of a direction under this subrule, a person is likely to fail to comply with a time limit imposed by the Ordinance or these Rules; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the failure were to occur, it would be attributable in whole or in part to an error or omission of the Registrar or the Registry,

subsection.continued: he may extend the period of time in question on such terms, if any, as he may direct.

subsection.content: Where the Registrar grants an extension of time in opposition proceedings, he may thereafter, if he thinks fit, without hearing the party in whose favour the extension is granted, grant any reasonable extension of the time or period in which any other party is required to take any subsequent step.
A period of time may be extended under this rule either before or after the period in question has expired.

subsection.leadIn: The periods of time specified in the following rules may not be extended under rule 94(1), namely—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: rule 11(2) (time for remedying deficiencies in an application for registration of a trade mark);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: rule 13(2) (time for filing representations or a request for amendment) (but see rule 13(3)); (L.N. 97 of 2003)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: rule 13(5) (time for filing representations, a request for amendment or a request for a hearing) (but see rule 13(6)); (L.N. 97 of 2003)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: rule 14 (prescribed period under section 42(3)(b) of the Ordinance);

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: rule 16(1) (time for filing a notice of opposition) (but see rule 16(4)); (L.N. 97 of 2003)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: rule 17(1) (time for filing a counter-statement) (but see rule 17(3)); (L.N. 97 of 2003)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: rule 26(2) (time for filing a notice of objection);

paragraph.name: h
i
paragraph.content: rule 33(2) (time for renewing registration);

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: rule 35(1) (time for restoring registration);

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: rule 37(1) (time for filing a counter-statement);

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: rule 41(1) (time for filing a counter-statement);

paragraph.name: m
paragraph.content: rule 50(3) (time for filing a counter-statement);

paragraph.name: n
paragraph.content: rule 55(1) (time for filing a notice of objection);

paragraph.name: o
paragraph.content: rule 61(1) (time for filing a notice of opposition);

paragraph.name: p
paragraph.content: rule 67(2) (time for filing a notice of opposition);

paragraph.name: q
paragraph.content: rule 73A(3) (time limit for the purposes of section 72(5)(d) of the Ordinance); (3 of 2020 s. 25)

paragraph.name: r
paragraph.content: rule 74(2) (time for filing a request for a hearing);

paragraph.name: s
paragraph.content: rule 102(3) (time for filing a notice of opposition);

paragraph.name: t
paragraph.content: rule 107(3) (time for filing an address for service);

paragraph.name: u
paragraph.content: rule 121(1)(a) (time for filing a notice of opposition) (but see rule 121(2)); and (L.N. 97 of 2003)

paragraph.name: v
paragraph.content: rule 121(1)(b) (time for filing a counter-statement) (but see rule 121(3)). (L.N. 97 of 2003)

subsection.content: The period of time for filing anything required to be included with or to accompany any document referred to in subrule (1) or to be filed at the same time as that document may not be extended under rule 94(1).
No period of time specified in rule 13(3) or (6), 16(4), 17(3) or 121(2) or (3) may be extended under rule 94(1). (L.N. 97 of 2003)

section.name: s96
section.heading: Extension of time limits in the case of an interruption in the Registry’s operations

subsection.content: Where on any day there is an event or circumstances causing an interruption in the normal operation of the Registry, the Registrar may notify the day as being one on which there is an interruption in the operations of the Registry.

Where any period of time specified in the Ordinance or these Rules, or as extended under these Rules, for the filing of any document or other thing with the Registrar expires on a day so notified, the period shall be extended to the first day next following (not being an excluded day) that is not so notified.
Any notification given by the Registrar under this rule shall be posted in the Registry.

subsection.def: In this rule, excluded day (除外日) means a day that is not a business day of the Registry.

part.name: P13
part.heading: Series Trade Marks, Defensive Trade Marks, Collective Marks and Certification Marks

section.name: s97
section.heading: Application for registration of series of trade marks

inline.i: (s. 51(1)(a) & (d) of the Ordinance) (Forms T2, T2A, T2S, T3 & T3S) (Fee Nos. 30 & 31)

subsection.content: The owner of a series consisting of not more than 4 trade marks may file an application on the specified form to register them as a series in a single registration.
The application shall be accompanied by a representation of each trade mark claimed to be in the series.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar shall accept an application filed under subrule (1) if he is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the series consists of not more than 4 trade marks; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the application satisfies the requirements for registration.

subsection.content: At any time before registration, an applicant under subrule (1) may file a request on the specified form for a division of his application into separate applications in respect of one or more of the trade marks in the series.

On receipt of a request under subrule (4) and payment of the applicable fee, the Registrar shall, if he is satisfied that the division conforms with rule 27(1) and (2), divide the application accordingly.
Rule 27(3), (4) and (5) applies to the division of an application under this rule.

section.name: s98
section.heading: Request to delete trade mark in series

subsection.content: An applicant for registration of a series of trade marks or the owner of a registered series of trade marks may at any time file a request on the specified form for the deletion of a trade mark in that series.
Where a request is filed under subrule (1), the Registrar shall delete the trade mark from the application or registration, as the case may be.

section.name: s99
section.heading: Application for registration of defensive trade mark

inline.i: (s. 60 of the Ordinance) (Forms T2, T2A & T2S) (Fee No. 32)

subsection.content: An application for the registration of a trade mark as a defensive trade mark under section 60 of the Ordinance shall be filed on the specified form.

subsection.leadIn: Within 9 months after the date of the application, the applicant shall file—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a statement of case setting forth full particulars of the facts on which the applicant relies in support of his application, verified by a statutory declaration or affidavit made by the applicant or some other person approved for the purpose by the Registrar; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such evidence, if any, as the applicant may desire to adduce in support of the application.

subsection.content: If the applicant does not file a statement of case within the period referred to in subrule (2)(a), the application shall be treated as abandoned.

The applicant may, within such time as the Registrar may allow, whether after request made by the Registrar or otherwise, file such other evidence as he may desire to adduce in support of the application, and the Registrar shall consider the whole of the evidence before deciding on the application.

For the avoidance of doubt, it is declared that the provisions of Part 2 apply in relation to an application for the registration of a trade mark as a defensive trade mark except to the extent they are inconsistent with this rule.

section.name: s100
section.heading: Application for registration of collective mark

subsection.content: For the purposes of section 6(3) of Schedule 3 to the Ordinance, an applicant for registration of a collective mark shall file a copy of the regulations governing the use of the mark within 9 months after the date of the application for registration.

The Registrar may send to the applicant any observations that he may wish to make with regard to the application or the suitability of the regulations, and the applicant may file a request under section 46 of the Ordinance to amend the application (see rule 24) or may modify the regulations, as appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of section 7 of Schedule 3 to the Ordinance and these Rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the period prescribed by rule 14(1), (2) or (3), whichever is applicable in the circumstances, shall be treated as being the period specified by the Registrar for the purposes of section 7(2) of that Schedule; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: rules 13 and 14, in their application to an application for registration of a collective mark, are to be read subject to the necessary modifications.

section.name: s101
section.heading: Application for registration of certification mark

subsection.content: For the purposes of section 7(3) of Schedule 4 to the Ordinance, an applicant for registration of a certification mark shall file a copy of the regulations governing the use of the mark within 9 months after the date of the application for registration.

The regulations shall be accompanied by evidence of the applicant’s competence to certify the goods or services for which the mark is to be registered, which evidence shall be verified by a statutory declaration or affidavit made by the applicant or some other person approved for the purpose by the Registrar.

The Registrar may send to the applicant any observations that he may wish to make with regard to the application, the suitability of the regulations or the sufficiency of the evidence, and the applicant may file a request under section 46 of the Ordinance to amend the application (see rule 24) or may modify the regulations or file new evidence, as appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of section 8 of Schedule 4 to the Ordinance and these Rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the period prescribed by rule 14(1), (2) or (3), whichever is applicable in the circumstances, shall be treated as being the period specified by the Registrar for the purposes of section 8(2) of that Schedule; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: rules 13 and 14, in their application to an application for registration of a certification mark, are to be read subject to the necessary modifications.

section.name: s102
section.heading: Amendment of regulations governing use of collective mark or certification mark

inline.i: (s. 10 of Sch. 3 & s. 11 of Sch. 4 to the Ordinance) (Form T6) (Fee No. 33)

subsection.content: An application by the owner of a registered collective mark or certification mark for the amendment of the regulations governing the use of the mark shall be filed in writing.

Where the Registrar considers it appropriate to do so, he shall publish a notice of the amendment in the official journal, which notice shall indicate where copies of the amended regulations may be inspected.

Where the Registrar publishes a notice under subrule (2), any person claiming to be affected by the amendment may, within 3 months after the date of publication of the notice, file a notice of opposition on the specified form.

The notice of opposition shall include a statement of the grounds of opposition, which statement shall, in particular, explain how the opponent would be affected by the amendment and why in the opponent’s opinion the amendment would be contrary to section 6(1) or (2) of Schedule 3 to the Ordinance (which deals with collective marks) or section 7(1) or (2) of Schedule 4 to the Ordinance (which deals with certification marks), as the case may be.
The opponent shall, at the same time as he files the notice of opposition, send a copy of it to the owner of the registered collective mark or certification mark in question.

subsection.leadIn: Where a notice of opposition is filed within the period specified in subrule (3), the Registrar may—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: if he is satisfied that the opposition is without merit and that the amendment should be accepted, accept the amendment as proposed by the owner.

subsection.content: If no notice of opposition is filed within the period specified in subrule (3) and the Registrar is satisfied that the amendment should be accepted, he shall accept the amendment as proposed by the owner.

section.name: s103
section.heading: Proof of authorization of agent may be required, etc.

subsection.content: Where a person has been authorized to act as an agent in accordance with section 88 of the Ordinance, the Registrar may in any particular case require the personal signature or presence of the agent or the person authorizing him to act as agent.
The Registrar may by notice in writing require any person who claims to act as an agent to produce evidence of his authority.

A person who is authorized by another person to act as his agent shall, on or before the first occasion on which he acts as agent, notify the Registrar of the address in Hong Kong where he resides or carries on his business activities, which notice shall be given in the specified form or in writing. (L.N. 39 of 2004)

If a person who has given notice under subrule (3) changes the address in Hong Kong where he resides or carries on his business activities, he shall notify the Registrar of the change as soon as practicable thereafter, which notice shall be given in the specified form or in writing. (L.N. 39 of 2004)

No act required or authorized by the Ordinance or these Rules to be done by or to any person may be done by or to an agent of that person before the date on which the agent notifies the Registrar in accordance with subrule (3). (L.N. 39 of 2004)

section.name: s104
section.heading: Registrar may refuse to deal with certain agents
section.leadIn: The Registrar may refuse to recognize as an agent in respect of any business under the Ordinance or these Rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person who has been convicted of a criminal offence;

paragraph.name: b
c
d
paragraph.content: a person against whom a disqualification order has been made under section 168E, 168F, 168G, 168H, 168J or 168L of the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32); (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a person against whom an order has been made under section 23(1)(a) or 24(1) of the repealed Securities (Insider Dealing) Ordinance (Cap. 395); or (L.N. 39 of 2004)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a person against whom an order has been made under section 214(2)(d), 257(1)(a), 258(1) or 303(2)(a) of the Securities and Futures Ordinance (Cap. 571).

tr.td: Note:
Section 88(3) of the Ordinance provides that the Registrar shall refuse to recognize as an agent a person having neither residence nor a place of business in Hong Kong. (L.N. 39 of 2004)

subsection.leadIn: An address for service shall be filed by every person who files—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an application for registration of a trade mark under rule 6;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a notice of opposition to the registration of a trade mark under rule 16;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a counter-statement under rule 17;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a notice of objection to the amendment of an application for registration of a trade mark under rule 26;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: an application for the revocation of the registration of a trade mark under rule 36;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a counter-statement under rule 37;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: an application for the revocation of the registration of a trade mark under rule 40;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: a counter-statement under rule 41;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: an application for a declaration of invalidity of the registration of a trade mark under rule 46;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: an application for the variation of the registration of a trade mark or for the rectification of an error or omission in the register under rule 48 and to which rule 50 applies;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: a counter-statement under rule 50(3);

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: an application for leave to intervene under rule 51;

paragraph.name: m
paragraph.content: a notice of objection to the alteration of a registered trade mark under rule 55;

paragraph.name: n
paragraph.content: a notice of opposition to the amendment of the specification of a registered trade mark under rule 61;

paragraph.name: o
paragraph.content: an application or notice to register particulars of a registrable transaction relating to a registered trade mark or an application for registration of a trade mark under rule 62;

paragraph.name: p
paragraph.content: a request to amend or remove registered particulars relating to a licence or security interest under rule 64;

paragraph.name: q
paragraph.content: a notice of opposition to the removal of any matter from the register under rule 67(2);

paragraph.name: r
paragraph.content: an application for leave to be substituted for a party under rule 83;

paragraph.name: s
paragraph.content: an application for registration of a series of trade marks under rule 97;

paragraph.name: t
paragraph.content: an application for registration of a trade mark as a defensive trade mark under rule 99;

paragraph.name: u
paragraph.content: a notice of opposition to the amendment of the regulations governing the use of a registered collective mark or certification mark under rule 102(3); or

paragraph.name: v
paragraph.content: any other document the specified form of which, if any, requires the person who completes the form to provide an address for service.

subsection.content: The address for service must be a residential or business address in Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: A person may file an address for service—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the document in question is required to be filed on the specified form and the form requires the person who completes it to provide an address for service, by filing the specified form with the address for service stated on it; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, by notifying the Registrar in writing.

subsection.content: Where a document referred to in subrule (1) is filed in the name of 2 or more persons, the address for service filed in relation to that document shall be treated as the address for service of each of those persons.
An applicant for registration of a trade mark may use only one address for service for the purposes of all proceedings before the Registrar concerning that application.
The owner of a registered trade mark may use only one address for service for the purposes of all proceedings before the Registrar concerning that registered trade mark.

Subject to any filing to the contrary under this rule or rule 106, on the registration of a trade mark, the address for service of the applicant for registration shall be treated as the address for service of the owner of the registered trade mark for the purposes of all proceedings before the Registrar concerning that registered trade mark.

Where a person files an address for service for the purposes of any proceedings before the Registrar, that address shall be treated as being in substitution for any address for service previously filed by that person for the purposes of those proceedings.

Where, after a person has become a party to proceedings before the Registrar, the person appoints an agent for the first time or appoints one agent in substitution for another, the newly appointed agent shall file an address for service.

No act required or authorized by the Ordinance or these Rules to be done by or to a person referred to in subrule (9) in connection with the proceedings in question may be done by or to the newly appointed agent before the date on which he files an address for service.

section.name: s106
section.heading: Changing or withdrawing address for service

subsection.leadIn: A person may change his address for service by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: filing the specified form; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: notifying the Registrar in writing.

subsection.content: If the address for service of the owner of a registered trade mark or of a party to any proceedings before the Registrar ceases to be valid, the owner or party, as the case may be, shall as soon as practicable thereafter change his address for service in the manner provided by subrule (1).
A person may withdraw his address for service by notifying the Registrar in writing.

section.name: s107
section.heading: Failure to file address for service

subsection.content: Where an address for service is not filed as required by rule 105, or where the Registrar is satisfied that the address for service of the owner of a registered trade mark or a party to any proceedings before the Registrar is no longer valid, the Registrar may send to the person concerned, at any of the addresses referred to in subrule (2), a notice to file an address for service.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subrule (1), the addresses are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any previously filed address for service of the person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any address of the person in Hong Kong that is shown in the register;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any residential or business address of the person in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other address of the person that is known to the Registrar.

subsection.leadIn: If any person to whom a notice is sent under subrule (1) fails to file an address for service within 2 months after the date of the notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any application, notice or request filed by that person shall be treated as abandoned or withdrawn; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person shall be deemed to have withdrawn from any proceedings before the Registrar of which he is a party.

section.name: s108
section.heading: Filing of documents with the Registrar

subsection.content: Any document or other thing required or authorized by the Ordinance or these Rules to be filed with the Registrar must be delivered by hand to the Registrar at the Registry during the normal business hours of the Registry or sent to the Registrar by post. (L.N. 62 of 2006)

Sending by post shall be deemed to be effected by properly addressing, preparing and posting a letter containing the document or other thing, with the postage on it prepaid, to the Registrar at the office of the Registry; and the document or thing shall be deemed to have been received at the time when the letter is actually received by the Registrar at the Registry.
The filing of a document or other thing with the Registrar shall be deemed to be effected at such time as it is received by the Registrar at the Registry and is recorded as received.

The Registrar may at his discretion permit, as an alternative to the filing of a document or other thing with the Registrar in a paper or other physical form, the filing of an electronic record of that document or thing.

The Registrar may at his discretion permit, as an alternative to delivering or sending a document or other thing to the Registrar in the manner provided by rule 108, the sending of an electronic record of that document or thing by electronic means to an information system designated by the Registrar.

The filing of an electronic record, and the sending of an electronic record by electronic means to the information system designated under subrule (2), shall be subject to such terms as the Registrar may specify either generally by notice published in the official journal or in any particular case by notice to the person desiring to file an electronic record or to send an electronic record to the Registrar by electronic means.

Where, in accordance with this rule, a document or other thing in the form of an electronic record is sent by electronic means to the information system designated under subrule (2), the filing of that document or thing shall be deemed to be effected at such time as that electronic record is accepted by the designated information system.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the generality of rule 109(3), the Registrar may specify terms under that rule—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: providing for the approval by the Registrar of the process that must be used to make or send an electronic record;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: providing for the approval by the Registrar of the format or media in which an electronic record must be recorded or stored;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: respecting the manner of authenticating an electronic record in circumstances where the document or other thing in question is required to be signed or sealed or authenticated in any manner;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: requiring any document or other thing sent to the Registrar in the form of an electronic record to include or be accompanied by the electronic signature or digital signature of the person who sends it; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: respecting the manner of filing a document or other thing in cases where there is an interruption in the operation of the information system designated under rule 109(2).

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the generality of rule 109(3), the Registrar may refuse to accept or to register any document or other thing that is in the form of an electronic record if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the information contained in the electronic record is not capable of being displayed in a legible form;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the electronic record is not capable of being stored in the information system designated under rule 109(2);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the electronic record appears to the Registrar to be altered, damaged or incomplete;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any electronic signature or digital signature or other kind of authentication accompanying or included with the electronic record appears to the Registrar to be altered or incomplete; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: any term specified by the Registrar under that rule has been breached.

subsection.content: On the request of any person, the Registrar may designate an electronic mail box within an information system designated by the Registrar which may be used by that person to communicate with the Registrar.

The use by any person of an electronic mail box within the designated information system shall be subject to such terms as the Registrar may specify either generally by notice published in the official journal or in any particular case by notice to the person for whom the electronic mail box is designated.

Where the Registrar designates an electronic mail box for a person under this rule, any document or other thing required or authorized by the Ordinance or these Rules to be sent by the Registrar to that person shall be deemed to be properly sent if it is sent in the form of an electronic record to that person’s designated electronic mail box.
Sending to a designated electronic mail box shall be deemed to be effected at such time as the electronic record is accepted by the designated information system.

An electronic record sent to a designated electronic mail box shall be deemed to be received by the addressee at such time as the electronic record is accepted and recorded by that electronic mail box.

subsection.leadIn: Except as provided by rules 108, 109, 110 and 111, where any document or other thing is required or authorized by the Ordinance or these Rules to be sent to any person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the document or other thing may be left at, or sent by post to, the address for service of the person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the person does not have an address for service, the document or other thing may be sent by post to his last known address.

subsection.content: Sending by post shall be deemed to be effected by properly addressing, preparing and posting a letter containing the document or other thing, with the postage on it prepaid, to the address for service of the person or, if he does not have an address for service, at his last known address, and unless the contrary is shown, the document or thing shall be deemed to have been received by that person at the time when the letter would be delivered in the ordinary course of post.

section.name: s113
section.heading: Form in which the records of the Registry are kept, etc.

subsection.content: The Registrar shall determine the form in which the records of the Registry are constituted and kept and may determine the period for which such records, or any document or other thing kept by the Registry, shall be kept and the circumstances in which they may be destroyed or otherwise disposed of.

Where the Registrar keeps a record of a document or other thing in a form that differs from that in which the document or thing was originally filed with, or originally generated by, the Registrar, the record of that document or thing shall be presumed, unless the contrary is shown, to accurately represent the information contained in the document or thing as originally filed or generated.

section.name: s114
section.heading: Publication of business hours and business days of the Registry
section.content: Any directions given by the Registrar under section 89 of the Ordinance (which authorizes the Registrar to specify the hours of business or business days of the Registry) shall be posted in the Registry and published in the official journal.

section.name: s115
section.heading: Publication and sale of documents
section.content: The Registrar may arrange for the publication and sale of documents and information by the Registry on such terms as he thinks fit.

section.name: s116
section.heading: Publication of certain court orders
section.content: Whenever an order is made by the court under the Ordinance for the rectification or correction of the register, the Registrar may, if he thinks that it should be made public, publish the order in the official journal.

section.name: s117
section.heading: Filing of court orders, declarations and certificates

subsection.content: If the court has made an order or declaration, or has granted a certificate, under the Ordinance in favour of a person, the person or, if there is more than one such person, the person directed by the court, must file a sealed copy of the order, declaration or certificate with the Registrar. (L.N. 92 of 2025)
Where appropriate, the Registrar shall rectify the register accordingly.

section.name: s118
section.heading: Signature of documents by partnerships, corporations, etc.

subsection.content: A document signed for or on behalf of a firm shall be signed by its partners, by any partner stating that he signs on behalf of the firm or by any other person who satisfies the Registrar that he is authorized to sign the document.

A document signed for or on behalf of a body corporate shall be signed by a director or the secretary or other principal officer of the body corporate or by any other person who satisfies the Registrar that he is authorized to sign the document.

A document signed for or on behalf of an unincorporated body or association of persons other than a firm shall be signed by a director, manager, secretary or other similar officer of that body or association, or by any other person who satisfies the Registrar that he is authorized to sign the document.

section.name: s119
section.heading: Change of language of proceedings
section.content: The Registrar may, subject to the consent of the parties concerned, give directions relating to the change of the language of proceedings on such terms as he may direct.

subsection.content: Except as expressly provided in these Rules, where any document or part of a document that is not in one of the official languages is filed with the Registrar, the document shall be accompanied by a translation of the document or that part of the document into the language of the proceedings and such translation must be verified to the satisfaction of the Registrar as corresponding to the original text.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar may, in respect of any document or part of a document to be used for the purposes of evidence in proceedings before the Registrar and that is in a language other than the language of the proceedings, give directions as to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the filing of the document or that part of the document in that other language; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the filing of a translation of the document or that part of the document into the language of the proceedings.

subsection.content: Where a person is required by the Ordinance or these Rules to state his name on any document filed with the Registrar and his name is not in the Roman alphabet or in Chinese characters, the document shall contain a transliteration of the name in the Roman alphabet.

In the case of an application for the registration of a trade mark that consists of or contains a word, letter or character that is neither in the Roman alphabet nor in Chinese characters, the application shall, unless the Registrar otherwise directs, include a translation or transliteration of that word, letter or character to the satisfaction of the Registrar, and where the application includes such a translation or transliteration, it shall also state the language to which that word, letter or character belongs.

In the case of an application for the registration of a trade mark that consists of or contains a word, letter or character in a language other than English or Chinese, the Registrar may require the applicant to file an exact translation of that word, letter or character into English or Chinese, and, if the Registrar so requires, the translation shall be endorsed and signed by the applicant or his agent and the endorsement shall state the language to which that word, letter or character belongs.

The Registrar may, in respect of any information required to be supplied by any person in connection with any proceedings before the Registrar, require the person to supply the information in one or both of the official languages on such terms as the Registrar thinks fit.
The Registrar may specify periods within which translations of documents or parts of documents are to be provided by a party to any proceedings before the Registrar.

subsection.leadIn: Where an application for registration of a mark made under the old law is advertised in accordance with section 14 or 66 of the repealed Ordinance on or after the commencement date*— (L.N. 97 of 2003)

The Registrar may, on a request being filed by the applicant on the specified form within the period specified in subrule (1)(b), extend the time for filing the counter-statement by 2 months, which time may not be further extended. (L.N. 97 of 2003)

section.heading: Form for conversion of pending applications
